content.webTitle: Has Jeremy Corbyn ended Labour unity with article 50 whip?

fields.headline: Has Jeremy Corbyn ended Labour unity with article 50 whip?
fields.bodyText: Last August, as Jeremy Corbyn’s ill-tempered leadership contest with Owen Smith crawled towards its inevitable conclusion, a crowd of 10,000 people gathered outside St George’s Hall, in Liverpool’s city centre, to hear the embattled Labour leader speak from the top of a fire engine. It was an extraordinary show of support for a leader whose apparently lukewarm opposition to Brexit, and call to invoke article 50 immediately on the morning of 24 June, had alienated almost all of his shadow cabinet and 172 of his MPs. Four months on from his second landslide victory, Corbyn’s stance on Brexit has once again thrown Labour into very public disarray. A new crop of frontbenchers, unwilling to invoke article 50, is in open revolt against the leadership’s imposition of a three-line whip on the government’s EU withdrawal bill. The Labour grassroots in areas that voted decisively for Remain, such as Liverpool (where 58% backed EU membership), are divided over the party’s direction on Europe – and unlike in previous policy debates, such as airstrikes in Syria, the party has not launched one of the online consultations Corbyn promised would revolutionise its internal democracy. It remains to be seen whether members will turn out in their thousands again to give their unconditional backing to Corbyn: even The Canary, the leftwing news website frequently parodied for its unflinching support for the Corbyn project, had turned against the Labour leader by Friday. “Corbyn has chosen to back the government without guaranteeing that the most vulnerable people, and the most valued principles of our participation in the EU project, will be protected post-Brexit,” read its editorial. “It is a decision that could sink his leadership of the party, and kill off any chance of a bona fide leftwing alternative among the national Westminster parties. This is a colossal mistake.” On Merseyside, among those unimpressed with Labour’s mixed messages on Brexit is Cieran Simpson, a third-year journalism undergraduate at Liverpool John Moores University, who paid £25 to vote for Corbyn as a registered supporter last summer and shares his socialist politics. But, convinced leaving the single market is a bad idea, he believes they need to provide much stronger opposition to a hard Brexit driven by the Tory right and Ukip. “Corbyn did a lot in the run-up to the referendum, but he wasn’t gung-ho about Remain and he’s still coming across that way – and that’s causing uncertainty among the electorate. That’s what a lot of people are annoyed with,” he said at Lime Street station on Friday evening. “If we want to convince people over Brexit, we have to be clear, and we have to get a firm, concise message out there in the press and on social media, like Theresa May has with ‘Brexit means Brexit’. People can latch on to that in a way that they haven’t been able to with our messaging.” In private, growing numbers of Labour MPs have criticised the party’s Brexit spokesman, Kier Starmer, as overly lawyerly, and are pressing ahead with their own policy initiatives. Simpson is from Seascale, the village in the West Cumbrian constituency of Copeland, home to the Sellafield nuclear decommissioning plant. He is largely sympathetic to Corbyn’s predicament, but he says the electorate’s uncertainty on where he stands, both on Brexit (62% in Copeland voted Leave) and the nuclear industry, could be the party’s undoing in next month’s crunch byelection, where the Tories are odds-on favourites to take the seat for the first time since 1935. Elsewhere in its provincial heartlands, Labour faces the ignominious prospect of losing Stoke-on-Trent Central, which it has held since 1950, to Ukip’s leader Paul Nuttall — for whom clarity on Brexit, and contentious issues such as free movement of EU migrants, is not an issue. But as this week’s Commons vote approaches, dozens of pro-Remain Labour MPs are preparing to ignore their leader and vote against triggering article 50. Liverpool Riverside’s Louise Ellman is among them. “I’m very clear. I’m not going to vote to trigger article 50, three-line whip or not. I’m elected to take my own decisions, and I’m very conscious that 73% of my constituents voted to remain,” she said. “The main reason for Liverpool’s transformation has been support from the EU, and I see absolutely nothing in the government’s plans that’s going to retain that support for Liverpool. The party as a whole has got a number of issues to consider. There were areas that were very supportive of leaving, though the people who voted for it weren’t always aware of the real implications of that. So I’m voting the way I am, I’m very firm about that. I’m not going to change.” The sheer complexity and overwhelming scope of the debate means members of Ellman’s constituency party are far from united behind her. “It’s a really complicated issue — it can’t just be summed up in a quote on an opposition candidate’s leaflet. We need to have a serious discussion about what politics means in 2017,” says city councillor Rachael O’Byrne, a Corbyn supporter who voted Remain and believes Labour’s ongoing internal debates, both locally and nationally, are a necessary evil. “Constituency MPs, and the leadership, are in a really difficult position. There’s a diverse range of opinion within the party and we need to discuss this collectively.” Other MPs in England’s major cities and university towns, frontbenchers among them, will vote in line with their constituencies and rebel on the article 50 bill. By Friday, shadow Wales secretary Jo Stevens and shadow early years minister Tulip Siddiq had already resigned, citing Remain majorities in their Cardiff and north London constituencies. Clive Lewis, the leftwing shadow business secretary tipped by bookmakers as a future leader, has pledged to vote against the third reading of the bill should Labour’s amendments fail to pass. Another 19 Labour backbenchers, including Siddiq, have put forward a Commons motion to throw out the government’s bill to trigger article 50, arguing they cannot support Theresa May’s plan to take Britain out of the EU’s single market. Labour’s divisions on Europe are the inevitable consequence of electoral arithmetic. While 65% of Labour voters backed Remain, 161 (roughly two-thirds) of its constituencies voted Leave. Any course of action the leadership takes is bound to alienate a chunk of the party’s base, but according to David Lammy, the Tottenham MP, its attempt to whip MPs into backing article 50 could have disastrous consequences. “It is shockingly bad politics,” he said. “Everyone understands Labour voters are split down the middle over Brexit, north and south, middle class and working class, young and old, but so too are the Tories. By taking a side and not allowing MPs to vote with their conscience, Labour’s leadership is forcing an exodus of Remain voters and members.” Even on Merseyside, says Liverpool University’s head of politics, Dr Stuart Wilks-Heeg, Brexit – and Corbyn’s “unbelievable” lack of a definitive argument – could change a political game dominated by Labour. The Lib Dems controlled the council as recently as 2010, and a flight of pro-EU voters, increasingly willing to forgive the sins of coalition, could add urgency to their sluggish comeback (they currently hold four seats to Labour’s 80, but hope to finish a strong second on a pro-EU platform in May’s mayoral election). Many scousers still loyal to Corbyn are increasingly pessimistic about the Brexit debate: they feel their man simply cannot win. Science teacher and stalwart supporter Stu Burcher, from Norris Green, joined Labour to vote for Corbyn in 2015 after briefly abandoning the party under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown. “Jeremy is in a position where he can’t please everyone,” he said. “He’s like a lot of the general public in that he’s only about 70% for Remain – and I was very much like that – and he’s doing the best he can. I don’t know what he can do. He’ll be criticised if he does a three-line whip, or if he allows a free vote.” Labour’s existential bind on Brexit means the problem as it stands is close to insoluble. Down the East Lancs Road in Leigh, Greater Manchester, Andy Burnham is one of a number of high-profile Remainers who have broken decisively with past Labour policy, backed the invocation of article 50 and called for the end of free movement (others include Chuka Umunna, Rachel Reeves, Pat McFadden, Stephen Kinnock and Emma Reynolds). “I struggle to see how, after a clear referendum result, parliament could somehow vote to not respect that result. Labour’s got to show that it understands that,” he said. • This article was amended on 29 January 2017. An earlier version said Clive Lewis was “widely tipped to harbour aspirations to replace his ally Corbyn as leader”. This has been corrected.
